properties.media:imagetext:
Honolulu, November 13th '63
Dear F and F (Family & Friends)
We took off for London at 9 a.m. on Oct. 30th. Our old friends
Chili Vaughn and 0. F.
Studeman both former pilots who are now executives
came over to the
Clipper lounge to see us off.
Chili said that we would
fly South of hurricane
Ginny and thus pick up a strong tail wind as hurri-
canes turn counter-clock wise.
Shortly after take off the Captain gave our estimated flight time
to London as 6:20, actually by my watch,
take off
to touch down was 6:19.
It is amazing how close the jets
come to forecast or perhaps I should say
the forecasts to the jets.
Of course they climb up above the weather so
your flight is smooth all the way.
We stayed at a little hotel in London called the Goring on Ebury
Street near Buckingham Palace.
The hotel is more than 50 years old and
boasts of
being the first hotel in the world to have a bath with every room,
the baths have changed very little in those fifty years.
But the beds are
comfortable, the service perfect, the rates reasonable and the food delicious.
On the 31st we had lunch at the Cog d'or with our old friend
Jack Kelly, PAA Vice-President for Europe.
That night we saw Lawrence of
Arabia - as Debby's father used to say of
some sermons - it could be condensed.
Saturday, November 2nd, we hired a car and drove down toward Hastings
to see our old friend Susan McCrindle.
Her husband Ronald was in N. Y.
was one of the top men in B.O.A.C. for many years.
We loved the drive through
the English country side
and Kent is especially beautiful.
The McCrindles
have a house built in 1766 with part of an old Moat around it.
Sunday, our old friends from Shanghai, Col. and Mrs. Wilfred Clark,
came up from Farnsborough to have lunch with us and we also had her blind son
Mike Alymer, his wife and little girl.
That morning we walked over to Hyde Park to see the start of the
antique cars racing to Brighton.
There were 250 entries from all over the
world and all cars were made prior to 1905.
The drivers and passengers
wore costumes of that time, deer-stalker hats, dusters and the lady's big
hats with veils.
of
course most of them do not finish the 50 mile drive in
the four hours allowed by the rules.
We left London at 10 a.m. on November 5th and again
the elapsed
time of the flight was forecast to
the minute.
Debby and I had both read
quite a few books about the 400 year search for the N. W. Passage including
a book
by Henry Cooper's brother, Paul, which dealt with the disappearance
of Sir John Franklin.
We recognized many of the names of islands, capes
and sounds as we passed over Hudson Bay.
It seems hard to believe but we
did the 5,514 miles from London to Los Angeles in just a little bit less
than half a day including a brief refueling stop at Winnepeg.
